claim: The majority of a set of numbers cannot be larger than the average.

supporting.text: By definition, the average (mean) of a set of numbers is the sum of all numbers divided by the count of numbers. For the majority of numbers to be larger than the average, the remaining numbers would have to be significantly smaller to balance the sum, which is mathematically implausible for a majority.

In a set with extreme outliers, the majority of numbers can indeed be larger than the average. For example, if the set is [1, 1, 1, 1, 100], the average is 20.8, and 4 out of 5 numbers (the majority) are smaller than the average.
The example given in B1 is a rare case and does not represent typical datasets. In most real-world scenarios without extreme outliers, the majority of numbers cannot be larger than the average.
